body.head: A Painful Discovery
body.p: A mounted messenger brought to Falkland Count a communication from Eunice Devereux to Hester Blayre, informing her that herself and brother had accepted an invitation from Lady Alton to pass a few days at Alton Hall.

Hester, after the agitation she had suddenly exhibited in Falkland Park while conversing with Gertrude, had, on reaching the old mansion, retired to her room, leaving to Gertrude the task of entertaining Valentine Temple.

The nature of the conversation which had taken place between Hester and Gertrude while walking together in the park had rendered the duty, thus unexpectedly devolving on the latter, one of considerable embarrassment. If she could have forgotten what had been said, Valentine Temple was not disposed to let it slumber on her mind.

No sooner did her presence gratify his eyes than he commenced a more than usually ardent course of attentions; for she was now with him alone. Eunice and the ever-intrusive Murray were away, and Hester Blayre, with her provokingly imperturbable manner and searching eyes, was absent. He felt that it was an opportunity not to be lost; he, therefore, although, still weak and ill, seized it in the hope that he should be able to surmount that distant reserve she displayed towards him, and create in her bosom an interest for him which should ripen under this cultivation into a passionate love.

He was quite aware that common means would have no effect with one of no common mould; he had observed that she possessed a kindly nature, and had displayed to himself and Murray equally tender sympathy for their sufferings. He was skilful enough not to proceed by language to woo her; but his looks and gestures superseded the necessity for words, while they gave him the advantage of being able to make himself understood without the risk which, if outspoken, he would have run of being requested not to repeat again expression to which there could be no such response as he wished.

When alone with her, he artfully drew her attention to himself, simulated acute anguish, and lamented his inability to wander abroad in the clear fresh sunny air for want of a protecting guide and companion. Gertrude glanced at his pale face, his wasting form, observed his writhing contortions, and fell into the trap he laid for her.

What if she were to offer to accompany him? To tender her arm for him to lean on, to conduct him to some of those fairy-like spots with which she had already made herself acquainted? What could come of it?

So when he looked out upon the fair landscape spread out like a map before him, and turned his eyes upward at the broad, bright blue sky, and sighed audibly as if heavy of hear, Gertrude asked him if he thought he had strength enough to attempt a short walk in the park.

He caught at the suggestion with such delight that she felt glad that she had made the proposition; but when she further suggested that she would summon his valet to attend him, an expression of such disappointment appeared on his face, and he declined the aid of his man in such strong terms, that when with earnest language he requested her to be his companion, if only for a few short paces, she could not find it in her heart to meet his solicitations with a refusal.
Together, therefore, they wandered under shadows of the broad elms and graceful beeches in the beautiful old park, with its undulating carpet-like surface and slopes.

This acquiescence of Gertrude's resulted in morning walks, in afternoon strolls, and, as the days grew longer, to evening rambles. Valentine rapidly increased in strength, his languor disappeared, his manner altogether underwent a remarkable change. He appeared to watch every look, every motion of Gertrude's. He studied her tastes, avoided any subject likely to prove displeasing to her, and preserved an air of deference and respect, which, while it distinctly proclaimed his passion for her, never overstepped the narrowest limit, so as to draw from her a single observation in reference to it.

She was not insensible to the position into which she gradually gliding nor to its dangers; but it had assumed that form which left her no alternative but to proceed, in order to avoid an explanation she had no wish to precipitate.

One thing she foresaw, and that was the speedy restoration of Valentine to convalescence. This moment arriving she would be enabled with grace, and without an invidious remark, to cease these perambulations. Then she world be absolved from the trial of having to endure, without a deprecatory word, soft loving glances, and a manner so ardent as to leave, as an expression of his sentiments towards her, nothing to her imagination. At least, such were her anticipations, or rather her resolves. She avoided, as far as possible, giving to the glances or the acts of Valentine the smallest encouragement; yet, to be complaisant and courteous, to display neither disquiet nor offence at the course he adopted, was in itself a tacit encouragement. He considered it such: and when the favorable moment, as he foreshadowed it, should arrive for him to declare himself, he determined to put very strongly to her how much his hopes had been advanced by the countenance she had extended to him; in fact, he had long since determined that she should be his; and if this object could not be accomplished by fair means, he resolved that no light considerations should deter him from attempting to make her his by far more questionable efforts.

In the meanwhile, Hester Blayre had resumed her usual appearance. Not a word had she let fall to Gertrude in explanation of the sudden excitement she had betrayed on beholding the person whose retreating figure Gertrude just caught a glimpse of; but Gertrude could trace an anxious look about her features, and an unsettled action in her eyes, which she had never before observed.

Hester appeared to notice only with favourable eyes the form which the intimacy between Gertrude and Valentine was assuming, and she suffered it to take its course without remark; but at the same time it was clear that she was more actively employed than had been the case since Gertrude had been with her. She was much occupied with receiving and answering letters, and passed a rather large proportion of time in her own room.

Gertrude could not but notice it; but she was unable to even guess the occasion for it. She had, however, a strong impression that the person Hester had encountered in the park was no other than the stranger she had met in the crypt beneath the dark firs. If this should prove to be the fact, it was evident that Hester knew his history, and that his sudden appearance was anything but a source of satisfaction to her. It occurred to Gertrude that this mysterious individual might be able to throw some light upon her past history. He had already said enough and acted in a manner to lead to such a conclusion; and she felt that if chance again threw her in his path, she would not avoid him, but, on the contrary, put to him questions which were the first and the nearest to her heart.
Hester Blayre had been startled by the announcement of the presence of Lady Alton at Alton Hall. She found it difficult to understand it.
However, it suited her schemes well for Lady Alton to be there; and she proceeded promptly to take such steps as would enable her to secure the advantages it might offer to her.

Among her letters from London there came one from Reuben Drake. She recognized the handwriting; and she opened it, expecting to find within the papers she had charged him with stealing; but there was no enclosure. Making herself certain that the letter contained nothing beyond three closely-written sides of paper, she held it over a taper and consumed it.

"I will not trust myself to read a word from him," she muttered — "no, not a word, even as I dare not trust myself to see his form or hear his voice. The summit of my wishes is too nearly within my reach for me to give way to weaknesses of the same nature as those of which I have been guilty. Let him go: he is but one more added to the many sacrifices this heart has made for the realization of a project which, after all, may prove to be mere profitless delusion. No, not that: it must not prove a chimera; no, not even if in the consummation of my revenge I pull down destruction on myself!"

She watched the paper consume until it was all destroyed, and then she flung the ashes into the grate. She flattered herself upon the resolution she displayed in this. She would have recoiled from such precipitancy had she divined even the character of the contents. It is true that she possessed some lurking fear, some latent uneasiness, that Reuben might prove himself a troublesome enemy; but she had so much faith in her own moral superiority, and the power which that gave her over him, that she would not suffer any dread of him to obtain in her mind.

Immediately after she became acquainted with the arrival of Lady Alton at Alton Hall, she, in harmony with the details of her secret scheme, summoned Sir Giffard Falkland to his country seat. She was all unconscious of what had passed between them in the earlier period of their lives, and had not the slightest knowledge of their accidental, but, as it proved, clandestine meeting in Kensington Gardens. She, unknowing that what had passed would materially assist the fatal purpose of her project, conceived a plan for accomplishing a series of private interviews between them, determining when the fitting moment arrived to introduce upon the scene Lord Alton.
Hester entertained no suspicion either of the purity of Lady Alton, nor of the honour of Sir Giffard Falkland, but she knew that —

body.p: To a man of the temperament of Lord Alton, of quick and sensitive pride, the mere fact of seeing Lady Alton alone in some sequestered place, with Sir Giffard Falkland, would be tantamount to a crime of the blackest dye. Hester did not pause to think that in inflicting the deepest possible wounds upon the heart of Lord Alton she might involve in the destruction of both Lady Alton and Sir Giffard. Revenge is ever a selfish passion; and those who strive to gratify it seldom contemplate, in striking at the object of their hatred, what other beings may suffer from the blow.

Hester Blayre was glad to think that Murray Devereux would remain a guest at Alton Hall. She had easily detected she was sufficiently mistress of his nature to feel assured that he had only to be alone for a week or so, subjected to the loving influence of a fond girl, conscious she had a rival in his affections, to make him commit himself to her attachment, declare his love for her, and place himself in her power beyond retraction, unless rejected by him who, as head of the household, claimed the title to dispose of his daughter's hand.

And she cared nothing about such a result, beyond the hope of exulting in that rejection, because she was interested only to the extent of creating dissension between father and daughter. To her it was a matter of indifference whether Murray and Laura married, or broke their hearts under an enforced separation; equally her object seemed secure. She knew Lord Alton to be inflexible, when he had formed plans for future family connections, and she thought she might safely judge by the step Laura had taken, in quitting Winchmore Park, that she would meekly, nor without murmuring, obey the behest of her father, never to see or think of Murray Devereux more.
The more, therefore, the fond couple were together, with opportunities for wooing in abundance surrounding them, the better for her project.

There was many points to be, however, carefully deliberated. She had not forgotten the part she felt it would be essential that Valentine Temple should play in this portion of the drama she was constructing, and she had not overlooked the fact that Valentine Temple was unconscious of the design Lord Alton had conceived of effecting an union between him and his daughter. She thought it was very important that he should know it, and that the information should be conveyed to him by her lips only.

Who can convey an insinuation with such an air of frankness as an artful woman? If a selfish man is to be possessed with an idea which may occasion his interests to clash with his honour, and he knows that in carrying it out he will not be any remove from a scoundrel, a designing woman can place it before him from a point of view where he can see it through the medium best suited to his own inclination, and at the same time the small voice of conscience is drowned by the shouts of "common sense." No one can do it so well. A woman's advice about woman naturally carries a very powerful influence to a man's mind; and if it should happen to square with the promptings of selfish passions, probity has but a poor chance.

Hester was too well acquainted with human weakness not to be aware of this; she sought for, and without difficulty obtained an interview with Valentine Temple, with no other person present but himself.

Inwardly sure of Gertrude's strength of character, and her perfect immunity from any danger of being triumphed over by the most cunning and seductive arts Valentine could employ, she had, in what appeared to be a cursory conversation to him, dwelt upon her character, enlarged upon what she said might be considered its principal attributes, decision and firmness; spoke tenderly and with seeming fondness of her; and when the attention of Valentine was intensely riveted to her observations, she expatiated upon the soft and loving, even passionate under-current which flowed steadily beneath that calm pool-like surface her manner exhibited to the circle with which she came in contact.

"She is but a woman, Mr. Temple," she said, with well-acted open ingenuousness, "a weak, loving, trusting woman; and I am quite convinced that if a man found his way to her heart, he would discover that the crystal he had so much admired was as pliable and as easily modeled to his views as others he had deemed of far less rocky consistency."
Valentine drew a deep breath.
"But Miss De Brent, madam," he said hastily, "I have always considered to possess a purity as invulnerable as adamant."
"Sir!" returned Hester, with well-affected warmth and surprise. "You misconceive the sentiments I have expressed. I spoke of the man who won the love of Miss De Brent."

"Ten thousand pardons, my dear Miss Hester, for a most unintentional, yet very improper observation," interrupted Valentine, with quickness. "Of course I am well aware that her nature is as immaculate and unsullied as snow; but I understood you — "
"No more; let us change the subject," interposed Hester, abruptly, but with a smile, as if to show that she was not offended. "I have a charge to make against you."
Valentine turned a violent scarlet. He bowed his head to conceal his confusion.
"Against me?" he exclaimed, in a low tone.
"Yes," she replied, perceiving but not noticing his confusion. Oh, she knew the nature of the soil she was planting, that she might reap the fruitful crop to which she looked forward!
"Pray prefer it," he said. "I have no doubt I can meet it with a satisfactory answer."

"It is quickly made," she returned. "You studiously avoid mentioning the name of Laura Alton; and truly if I did not happen to be conscious of your engagement with her, I should be more than half disposed to believe you sought to form one with my near relative, Gertrude De Brent."

Valentine gazed upon her with an air of astonishment. Laura Alton he had met several times, but no circumstances had arisen which had induced him to take more than common notice of her. He placed her in the same category with hundreds whom he had met. She had won from him a passing glance; he had exchanged with her the accustomed salutations exacted by good breeding, nothing more. When, therefore, Hester Blayre referred to an engagement with her, she so nonplussed him, that he at once, in plain terms, asked for an explanation.

Hester gave it him — but in her own way. She dwelt so pertinently upon the advantages to him of forming an alliance with her, that he began to regard it in the way she desired it, and to set in motion schemes having connection with it.

Hester carefully avoided making any allusion to the love Laura entertained for Murray Devereux; it was part of her plan to let Valentine make that discovery for himself; but after prolonging the conversation until it had reached the limit beyond which she did not wish it to extend, she closed it, quitting him that he might have the opportunity of reflecting upon what she had communicated to him, and the course he should pursue in consequence.

He did reflect. His selfish passions were at once set in motion. An alliance with the daughter of Lord Alton presented many advantages which had not occurred to him before, because he had not thought anything of the lady herself; but now he remembered that she was prepossessing in feature and elegantly formed, and a marriage with her would not be so great a personal sacrifice as he at first imagined it would be; yet if it had been, there were so many considerations which would induce him to make it, that throwing himself away would have formed only a secondary matter in the interests involved.

No man, let his position be what it may, can with impunity pursue a career of profligacy without penalty. Wealth and rank may do much to shelter an individual morally base from the consequences of his dissolute practices, but they cannot wholly screen him from a punishment of some kind. Valentine almost uninterruptedly had from an early period of his life, followed a course of moral debasement, but he had employed a large amount of artifice in the pursuit of his depraved pleasures. He had endeavoured by the exercise of caution to make the world believe that the worst it could say of him was that he was a male flirt. The heavy wrongs he had done in several instances he sought to keep as quiet, as private, and unknown, as cunning precaution could accomplish; but it was the source of constant disquietude to him, and had very nearly arrived at an exposé of a most unpleasant kind, when the attack was made upon him in the vicinity of Acton. He had barely escaped it, and was still suffering from its effects. What had happened to his assailants he longed, yet dreaded to hear. His impression was — and it was only too frequently the subject of his thoughts — that he had ridden them both down. He had a dim sense that when his horse plunged madly forward the wheels had rolled over some objects above the level of the road. He could only surmise that the officer by whom he was attacked, and his friend who had sprung to his fiery animal's head, were run over by the cab; and the strange silence which followed that all-but tragical event, almost confirmed him in the impression he had formed. He hoped that it might be so, for he knew that when that assailant, even under more favourable circumstances for him, stood before him again, an avenger was at hand.

He had detected the change which had taken place in the manner of Murray Devereux towards him; he felt that he owed to him an explanation, one he was only too anxious to avoid, because he saw plainly enough that the few observations he had made in reference to it to Murray did not carry conviction to the mind of the latter.

A marriage into the family of Lord Alton he felt would give him a stronger influence in the world, it would render his position in many ways more secure. His own future expectations might or might not be realized, but in the union so strangely suggested by Hester Blayre there was a certain security he could not so immediately obtain in any other way.

He paced his room in a state of mental excitement to which he had long been unaccustomed. It was not only that a sudden and important opening was presented to him, but it was that the form of Gertrude interfered with every attempt he made to realize a vision of Laura Alton. Amid all his selfish, and even mercenary considerations — for, gambler-like, he was hungry after wealth, let it come from whence or how it might — his passion for Gertrude obtruded itself.

To wed Laura Alton was to abandon all thoughts of Gertrude, but to root her out of his heart was not possible. The more the necessity for such an effort increased in the magnitude of its importance, the less did he find himself capable of effecting it. To part with Gertrude for ever he could not; sanguine hopes and fancies rose up, wild schemes, fatal to her peace, presented themselves, but her station, and then her character, were formidable obstacles to any such fancies or schemes, and he knew it.

The words of Hester had, however, taken a fast hold of his mind. "She is but a woman!" he thought; "'a loving, trusting woman': those were her words, and if I can but find the way to her heart, what has her station or her character to do with the power I could at once assume over it? By Heaven but I will try. There is yet time. I could sacrifice a thousand Lauras for her, yet not her for all the world." Remembering that Hester had told him Gertrude was in the park while they were conversing, he took his hat and cane, and made his way where he thought it most probable he might find her.

"Beneath the purple shadows of leafy branches, in some soft grassy dell" he murmured, soliloquising as he went, "glittering with starry-eyed and crimson-lipped flowers, or by the side of a clear, cool, winding stream, tinted with overhanging trees—the clear blue sky gleaming here and there, with no sound in the air save the low-breathed music of the rippling waters gliding over the pebbles, or the dreamy hum of bees chanting over blossoms—then a woman's heart is disposed to love: she will listen with patience to ardent words from him to whom her heart is still indifferent. In such a place a maiden may be always wooed, and in test cases won. Gertrude is scarcely of the ordinary mould yet, even under such influencee, her reserve tones down, the expression of her eye softens, and her voice modulates to a gentle music it has not in other places. What if I find her in the elm-grove? I can, unconsciously to herself, direct her course to some such place and try those arts to win her love which, until now, I have used in pastime, but which are now—out upon me for a weak fool!—to be employed in passionate earnestness."

He groaned, and pressed his hands to his temples as the conviction that he was madly in love forced itself upon him; as he saw there was no escape for him, for he could not at least part with that love for a new one, and, that it would cling to him, tinting everything he should in future see with its own hue.

He hated himself for being in love in spite of himself; he cursed the passion which defied his control, and would, unless he could win Gertrude, mar all his future happiness. If he were compelled to that course, he would marry her, if it should prove the only means of obtaining her, in preference to Laura Alton; but he would rather have her love than her hand, and that he resolved to try his utmost to win.

He rambled at a slow pace through the park in the direction in which Gertrude had usually conducted him; but he went on and on through the lonely sequestered places with which the wood abounded with watchful eye and listening ear. He could not, however, light upon a trace of her flowiung garments, nor perceive the print of her small foot upon the shining grass.
At last he stood still with the intention of returning, when suddenly the love murmuring of human voices caught his ear, and he softly moved towards the place from whence the sounds proceeded.

He passed at a spot where he could just distinguish the words so as to catch their meaning. He heard expressions of endearment, and he felt himself grow cold as marble, as he recognised the tone of one of the voices.

He approached yet closer, and between a small opening he beheld, with an astonishment no words can depict, Gertrude De Brent folded in the embrace of a man enveloped in a military cloak. He saw with infuriated wrath Gertrude raise the hand of him who caressed her to her lips, and imprint a fervent kiss upon it. Then they suddenly separated, and each, with hurried footsteps, took a different direction, Gertrude advancing with rapid steps towards the spot where Valentine stood, yet unseen by her.
Suddenly she reached the tree beneath whose shadow he stood, and he stepped before her.
She uttered a sudden cry.

"Pray be not alarmed, Miss De Brent," he exclaimed, in a sarcastic tone; "permit me to apologise for intruding upon you. I fear I intercepted a little téte-á-téte, which would have been only too agreeable had I been the hero of it."
"Gracious Heaven!" ejaculated Gertrude, "and you beheld—"
She checked herself, and for a moment remained silent.
"Shall I supply the omission, Miss De Brent, by a description of the gentleman ?" he said in the same tone.
She displayed agitation and confusion.

"Mr. Temple," she exclaimed, hurriedly, "I confess I have a secret which I would not for worlds at this moment have revealed. As a gentleman, may I ask you to keep within your own breast what you have thus accidentally discovered?"

"Anything you may ask of me, Miss De Brent," he said, with strong emphasis, "you may look upon in the light of a command, and be sure that it will meet with obedience. I confess I had rather it had assumed any other shape; but, be assured, your secret is safe with me."

"I thank you, sir," she said, in a colder manner than before, for she liked neither his look nor his tone of voice. "I admit the incident has a strange appearance, but at the proper moment it will be fully and satisfactorialy explained. Until the period only to which I allude, I request your forbearance."

"It is yours, Miss De Brent," he replied, with a more lively air. "I only ask in return from you, a mien less restrained, a glance more kind and words less carefully considered before they are spoken."
Gertrude, with a haughty bow, passed on. He gazed after her.

"I care not for scornful glances, nor haughty bearing; I have her in my power; her secret is mine. She knows not how much I have discovered, nor shall I inform her; but I will bring her like a falcon-gentil to my wrist."
So muttering, he slowly followed her towards Falkland Court.
